Plastic insert for the ElevationLabs Elevation Dock to use an Apple Lightning cable instead of the 30 pin dock adapter it comes with. This is orginally based on the thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:31429 but the calibration between whatever was made to print that and my replicator is off. The lighting cable would not even fit in to the rectangular hole they used.

So I took their idea and made my own version. Since the tolerances are pretty tight on this and every printer is slightly different at those tolerances you may need to tweak the OpenSCAD file to produce a STL that is useable. But hey, that is why this is all up on thingiverse. I used the lightning adapter cutout from another one of my designs for this. This means that it is pretty much flush with the top of the plug, and it has a bottom so that you can not (easily at least) push it out by docking your iPhone. Also the friction fit of the bottom plate was not as good as I wanted and repeated dockings would slowly push it out so I decided to use the two holes provided so you could screw this into the elevation dock and not have it go anywhere. I use two M3 8mm bolts. The source for this is also up at github at: https://github.com/scanner/elevation_dock_lightning_adapter

title: Cap / tip protector for colored pencils

description.text:
A cap for round pencils. Slide it on and give it a little press, and a tapered ring inside lightly grips the tapered part of the pencil body to keep the cap on. Slots near the end let you see the tip.  
I designed this for use on a couple of fabric marking pencils so I could just toss them in a bin with other tools and not have the tips getting broken all the time. It should fit most colored pencils. Writing pencils might bottom out since they're usually sharpened at a narrower angle.
For best results, print open-side-up.

comments.text: Me again! I printed the cap using a raft (a waffle type base) and it printed perfectly upright. The cap works as it should and is a great design and concept. Nice job!!
comments.author: robrook

comments.text: I tried printing one of these today on a 3D CUBE. About 1/3 the way through it fell over and the print was ruined. It needs a larger base in order to remain upright during the print. I will try building one with a raft.

title: [OLD VERSION] Folk flute, alto, straight bore

description.text:
This is an alto sized flute with folk fingering system (like a penny-whistle). Consists of three sections, which slide together. The bore shape and hole parameters have been designed using Python package "demakein" so that the flute is in tune over two octaves. Thanks to John Boshua for the excellent print in ABS plastic. Sample audio:
http://soundcloud.com/paul-francis-harrison/adew-dundee-3d-printed-flute

The joints have 0.3mm clearance all around. If the print turns out too tight, a little sanding should loosen it sufficiently. The joints need to form a tight seal. A little wax or grease should achieve this. To identify leaks, try covering all the holes and blowing into the instrument as if giving mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, first with just the head, then the first two segments, then all three segments. See the file "folk-flute-fingering.pdf" for the fingering chart. You can adjust the design by installing the Python package "demakein". For example you can use demakein to design a flute in the key that you want, or that has a tapered rather than straight bore, or with a different joint clearance. Demakein can also produce shapes for CNC-milling in wood. http://www.logarithmic.net/pfh/design
http://pypi.python.org/pypi/demakein If you can program in Python, demakein can be extended to produce designs for other woodwind instruments. I will be adding further built-in designs over the coming weeks.

This is a soprano sized flute with a recorder-like fingering system. Like a recorder, much of the chromatic scale is available by cross-fingering. Consists of three sections, which slide together. The bore shape and hole parameters have been designed using Python package "demakein" so that the flute is in tune over two octaves. The holes are angled to provide a comfortable spacing. Note that this is a somewhat complex fingering system. If you're familiary with recorder, cool. If your're after something simple to play like a fife, perhaps try this model instead: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:38865 Thanks to John Boshua for the excellent print in ABS plastic. I added some decorative rings to the design, after it was printed.

Printing height is 113.5mm. The joints have 0.35mm clearance all around. The joints need to form a tight seal. Blue teflon plumbing tape appears to work quite well for this. See the file "pflute-fingering.pdf" for the fingering chart. You can adjust the design by installing the Python package "demakein". For example you can use demakein to design a flute in the key that you want, or that has a straight rather than tapered bore, or with a different joint clearance. Demakein can also produce shapes for CNC-milling in wood. http://logarithmic.net/pfh/design
http://pypi.python.org/pypi/demakein If you can program in Python, demakein can be extended to produce designs for other woodwind instruments. I will be adding further built-in designs over the coming weeks.

title: Printrbot Simple Extensible X-Axis and GT2 Upgrade

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/fTVNxSo5Evi Using the $20 GT2 upgrade parts from http://www.printrbot.com, I was able to combine the extensible X-axis mod and a GT2 mod so that I can print over the entire build plate with no X-axis slippage. I believe these parts are still printable on a stock, Printrbot Simple V2, if rotated and possibly printed without a skirt.

Download all files, buy the $20 upgrade kit from http://printrbot.com/shop/gt2-kit/ , print however you can manage with your current build volume, find a new build plate (got mine from A.C. Moore). Be careful to make sure the +Y-most edge of the build plate does not interfere with the GT2 pulley brim before you drill mounting holes. Personally, I bought about 3 feet of 5/16" metal rod from Home Depot and cut it in half with a hacksaw to get a longer X axis, but the original rods should also work.

comments.text: Is this designed to fit the original build plate?
comments.author: jeffro1265

comments.text: I believe it should work on the original build plate, at least if it is rotated and you avoid the skirt and brim options in slic3r.It is derived from the non-GT2 mod I did with a similar name, and that mod could be printed on the original printer (and this one didn't get any wider).
comments.author: jeffro1265

comments.text:
I was able to print it out in the original build area when rotating the Z axis 45*. However, what i meant was will the original build plate bolt directly to this, and the answer is no. I ended up taking a dremel and making the shaft holes on one side thru holes so i could use any size plate. I drilled new holes that line up with the original holes of the simple plate to make it work. tonight ill run a test print and see how it goes.
If only i could figure out how to edit STLs.
comments.author: Elkniwt

comments.text:
Oh... right. I had taken those original holes out. Even with them, you would have to have just the right length rods (not the originals) in order to use this with the original plate.
You should look into using tinkercad (I think I provided a link in the description). It allows you to import and export STL files... or you could just modify the original model. Last I knew, accounts were still free.

author: thomasleeters

title: Elder Sign Card and Token Organizers

description.text:
So I padded the inside of the bottom box with foam and felt to use as a dice rolling box, and turns out I needed a new and fancy way to keep all the cards and tokens organized.
 
The large card holders are for the adventure, investigator, old god and other world cards.
 
Smaller card holder is for the items, blessing/curse, ally, spells, etc.
The extension seen with one of the large card holders is to accommodate for the height of the deck because all of my cards are sleeved and I also use the expansion, Unseen Forces.
 
All holders are designed with these goals in mind:
  • Fit all the cards with the FFG sleeves.
  • All fit back into the original box.
  • Includes Unseen Forces expansion.
  • Lid must close flush with the box with the manual on top.
  • Token Holder sits on top of the token holders in the grooves. With the arrow down it won't slide around.
     
    I've redesigned the whole layout measurements and containers. With a single layer of felt adhered to the inside of the sides of the box, and a layer of foam and felt on the bottom, the box itself becomes a fantastic dice rolling box. Because of this, the box now has the following measurements:
     
  • 245mm x 245mm x 43mm
     
    The tallest the containers go is 40mm, this allows 3mm for the book to rest on top and allow the lid to close flush.
     
    There are notches in the triple slot token holder for the time dial. With the arrow facing down, it fits into the container flush.
     
    The constraints of all of the pieces pushed together in a square fit exactly 245mm x 245mm x 40mm. The dice and investigator token boxes are 37mm so that the time dial extends over them neatly.
     
    As soon as I've finished printing off the last of the pieces I'll provide pictures of the layout. (We have a makerbot in the office for everyone to use, and it's been nothing but broken for the last couple months with all the bads using it thinking they know what they are doing).
     
    I'm completely open to suggestions on how to make this better or more awesome. There is no container for the bulk of the monster tokens as I found an awesome bag to draw from and left a void for the bag to fit. However if anyone requests, I have no problem quickly throwing together an additional container to sit in that void. Let me know, I have no problem making it for you. Hell I may do it anyway since it will only take a couple seconds to do.

To get the whole setup you need to print the following:
 
1x Mythos Card Holder
1x Extra Monster Token Holder
5x Small Card holders
1x Clue Sign Terror Holder
2x Large Card Holder
1x Stamina Sanity Holder
2x Dice Investigator Holder

A wonderful blend of digital and analogue tech.

wire it up with a 3v lithium battery
sew it to the glove
ask lots of questions!

title: Parametric tabletop spool holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A fully parametric and fully printable tabletop spool holder, designed to use the least amount of plastic (~50cm³).
All parts can be printed in one go on one tray, even with a relatively small machine (min 170×170).

Thingiverse page: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:316211
Git repository: https://cgit.pacien.net/public/cad/tabletop-spool-holder/

• material thickness and spaces between the different pieces
  • length and radius of the rod
  • height of the pillars
  • length and height of the bases

Please don't scale the .stl. You can adjust the design according to your needs by editing the variables in the attached OpenSCAD file. Customizable parameters are:
  • material thickness and spaces between the different pieces
  • length and radius of the rod
  • height of the pillars
  • length and height of the bases
    • The material saving mode that makes the pieces hollow can be disabled, even though they should already be robust enough.

Comment out the preview function call (put "//" before "preview_all()") and uncomment the ones concerning the pieces that you want to make, or "print_all()" if you want to print all pieces on one tray. Then, compile and render (F6), export as STL and slice :) Sucessfully printed using:
  • ABS and PLA
  • 20% infill
  • 0.3mm layer height

description.text:
I have the DLO HybridShell for iPhone 3G, 3G S case for my iPhone. All the car mounts I found for the iPhone were custom fit for a iPhone without a case, so I had to build a custom holder, and this is what I came up with.
I have used this for a month or so driving tractor and my iPhone never once jumped out of it. It is open on the bottom so the charger can be plugged in. I just mounted it with double sided tape, and it worked fine.

I cut out the parts with a water jet. I had to use two centerpieces because I did not have thick enough aluminum. If using thinner stock just stack up as many as needed. I then just used 4 machine screws to hold everything together. This is the case this thing was built for:
http://www.amazon.com/DLO-HybridShell-iPhone-3G-Black/dp/B001DC9UCI/ref=sr_1_15?ie=UTF8&s=wireless&qid=1274234177&sr=8-15 If you make it I would love to see a picture.

This microscope is designed to be used as a teaching tool for students learning about the fundamentals of a microscope. We estimated that this cost about $0.40 /microscope. We pre-cut the microscope parts for the students and they assembled it using the video provided in the attached link. Once they confirmed function, they were asked to label the parts (note the extensive decorations). Finally, they were asked to extend upon it by suggesting improvements and using the iPad attachment to observe objects through the iPad screen.
Here's the blog entry describing the project at Castilleja http://bournidealab.posterous.com/lets-build-a-microscope

This is designed to be cut from 1/4" plywood. This specific project was done using Home Depot 5mm Purebond. The mirrors should be cut out of mirrored acrylic.
The lens for this microscope need to come from a disposable camera.
Here is a video explaining how to assemble it.
http://youtu.be/fs4r2dtfWE0 If you are a teacher interested in projects like this, please contact me and follow zombie-cat.org

author: TurdFerguson

description.text: Rock out with this hand.

This is a modification of the mendel90's x-carriage that adds a z probe.  When used with new firmware (MatterPrint3D) your mendel90 can auto calibrate the bed height and dynamically compensate to ensure level.

Stuff you will need. 1 - printed x-carriage
1 - printed z-probe-mount
1 - printed up-down-bar
5 - 2.5m x 12m socket head cap screws
1 - 3m x 25m socket head cap screw
4 - 3m washers
1 - 3m nyloc nut
1 - mechanical limit switch
2 - 10mm x 5mm x 3mm neodymium magnets (ours came from a sonicare brush head)
MaterPrint3D firmware: https://bitbucket.org/MatterHackers/matterprint3d Procedure
  • Print out the new x-carriage, z-probe-mount and up-down-bar.
  • Press the magnets into the holes on the x-carriage.
  • Attache the limit switch to the z-probe-mount with 2x 2.5m x 12 screws
  • Attache the up-down-bar to the z-probe-mount with 2x 2.5m x 12 screws and put on nuts.
  • Attache the z-probe-mount to the x-carriage with the 3m x 25 screws placing a washer after the screw head, between the carriage edge and the probe edge on both sides, and before the nyloc nut.
  • Put the new mount on you mendel90.
  • Drill a 2.2mm hole into your mendel90 frame, 9mm from the left inside cut out and 5mm above the bottom of the cut out. This will hold the raising and lowing pin.
  • Insert one 2.5m x 12 screw into the raising and lowering pin hole.
  • Hook up the z-probe to the z-min switch connection.
  • Add a G29 to your slic3r custom g-code config just after the G28 (home all axis).
    • You can read our article and see videos at: https://www.matterhackers.com/news/automatic-printer-calibration-update Currently MatterPrint3D is only set up to work with RAMPS boards. If you have another board you will have to get the z-bed switch working on the z-min switch for your printer. If you do, we would love to have your patch. Have fun printing, Lars.

title: Marker-Minder - Whiteboard / Mr. Sketch / Flipchart Marker Quick-Draw Cap Clamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
You may have to toy with the z scale to get this to fit just the way you want. It also works great for kids to use, especially if you clamp it down to a tabletop, etc. I spent a year developing this product for market, then ran out of time and energy to continue developing it. I continue to own all marks and rights -- you may download and make it for free! This is the original one-piece cap clamp for quick color-coding on whiteboard or flipchart. The teacher or presenter can now decide on one of six colors, grab it, use it, and put it back without even looking. This also has notches for insertion into a desk stand, for example for one-handed use. I originally designed it and built one out of wood just to help myself present math in a classroom -- color-coding is important to comprehension, but I'm colorblind! I recommend: black, black, red, green, blue, highlight color.
Alternately I recommend: black, red, yellow, green, blue, purple. If requested, I can try to create one that will print on a smaller printer (i.e. 8" x 8" x 8" print volume). A four-by-four version would fit if printed already connected.

In collaboration with a friend who is a master of CAD software, I used multiple measures to craft the design. We rapid prototyped it, then analyzed the fit of the caps and determined what other features should be added. We had three versions rapid prototyped over the course of five months. By the end of our study we determined the final version here, v3.8, to be market-ready. As a parent with a full-time job, doing the legwork to get this onto shelves proved impossible without sacrificing too much quality of life. It is also ready for such things as cap adapters, so we can create whiteboard marker cap -> other item holder adapters for the following: Fountain pen
Hobby knife
Measuring Tape
Highlighter
Small hand tools
Glass working tools
Files Each lower cap recess has a keyway so things like threaded adapters can be used, in case certain tools are screw-in only. Please feel free to design cap adapters for ANY purpose!

title: Folded Spool for Proto Pasta coiled filament

description.text:
A Print in one go spool and mounting axle with a central roller bearing sized to fit the coils of Proto-Pasta filament.  
The spool unfolds to hold a coil of filament 50x30 mm with an internal diameter around 160 mm.  
Just unfold the two parts and push the mount into the hub.  
Printed in ~3 hours on a Replicator 2 using Makerware "Low" setting i.e. 0.3 mm layer height, 10 % fill, 2 shells, 90 mm/s travel.

comments.text:
I think this is a great design.
I printed one out and I'd like to offer my experience briefly.
I'm printing on a Da Vinci 1.0. The Da Vinci has a .4 extruder nozzle.
I printed at 10% in-fill.
Shells/Perimeters = 2 / "Normal"
Layer height = .1
Speed = "Standard"
The center bearing became joined and was unable to rotate without forcefully penetrating it with an edge (very messy).
The mount legs also became joined along the bottom side, but it was much easier to separate them with an edge since it was along a straight line rather unlike the circular curve of the center bearing.
The two prongs which the center bearings rotate on are not long enough and do not fit correctly with the bearings facing to the rear, mount legs facing forward. But they DO fit with the bearing facing forward, mount legs facing forward.
I'm not sure the purpose of the rotating center bearings since the whole thing rotates quite well even without the center moving. Even after freeing the center bearing and enabling it to rotate, they do not because there isnt sufficient friction from the prongs and the center bearing inside surface.
I might work just as well if the center bearing didn't rotate at all, but the prongs lip edges fit into a groove along the inside of the center bearing surface. Either that, or the prongs need to fit and secure more snugly and LOCK into the center bearing somehow.
Each of the three unfolding arms broke off as I tried to unfold them because the hinges adhered at the joint.
All that said, once again I think it's a BRILLIANT design. I'm going to attempt another print and change some of my settings to see if I get an improved result. Thankfully, because the mount printed with no damage I only have to print the filament holder.
I will post the results :) Thanks
comments.author: gldndragon77

comments.text: Thanks for your comments, The bearing is a little tight, but mine (I've printed about 4 of these) have all released reasonably easily and I had no trouble with the other hinges.  I printed at 0.3mm layer height and I get very little "squishing" of the filament on the bed that would cause distortion on the bottom edge.  It may be worth trying to print with a reduced layer height and maybe on a raft?  Cheers.

title: Stay Tab Bending Pliers Jaw Insert

description.text: I have this trick of making chain mail with soda can tabs. The mail looks best if all the tabs are bent to exactly the same angle, which is very hard to do without a jig.  So I printed this custom insert for a commercial pair of jeweler's forming pliers, which indexes and bends a single tab exactly the same way each time.

Print on FFF platform of your choice. It fits in place of the factory nylon jaw in Rio Grande's Forming Pliers with One Nylon Jaw (catalog #111605) using two small (#3?) wood screws through factory mounting holes in underside of jaw. http://www.riogrande.com/Product/Forming-Pliers-with-One-Nylon-Jaw/111605 For more info on the stay-tab chainmail technique, see http://makeprojects.com/Project/Pop-Top-Lamp-Shade/898/1

So, I had a hard time removing and remounting my Magpul CTR stock on my M4 airsoft rifle. Therefore, I created this tiny helping tool to easily aid the removal and remounting of this awesome Magpul CTR stock. This is a rather small item, so if it's lost or break, just print another one - hey, it only takes 4 minutes.  
When mounting the Magpul stock, simply press down on the locking pin inside the stock until the Magpul CTR stock remover fits as shown in the pictures. Now when pressing the release handle, the stock can be easily removed.  
When removing the stock, simply slide the stock out to an unlocked position, fit the tiny helper tool and follow normal procedure.  
Remember that this little tool holds back a rather powerful spring and therefore it can slip and fly off in a random direction. Watch your eyes and fingers. I claim no responsibility to any damage done :)
Just hit print with no supports - it'll take about 5 mins to print. Since I don't have my settings under total control, the Magpul CTR stock helper needed a bit of sanding in post-printing.

This is my brand new interlocking puzzle design that should print perfectly on a well tuned printer.
It consists of three pieces and makes a 3x3x3 cube.
It isn't too difficult to solve but is the first design that is both interlocking and fully printable without support.

This will test how accurately your slicer/printer combination can print simple objects. I tried a range of offset distances and found that creating pieces with every face offset inwards by 0.1 mm gives the best fit.
The model has a base cube size of 6 mm giving a finished puzzle of just under 1.8 cm whilst using very little filament. Feel free to scale the puzzle up for a larger version but be aware that this will tend to make the pieces fit more loosely.
I used a 0.2 mm layer height and 0.3 mm extruded width from a 0.3 mm nozzle.
Use medium infill to make sure that you get a nice smooth top layer.
Finally, use a craft knife to remove any extraneous bobbles that might jam the pieces together.

title: Rostock Modded Parts - Carriage, Platform (for Ball Links); Belt Spreader; Corner Support

description.text:
Various modded files for the Rostock Delta 3D Printer:
-- Carriage with screw LM8UU mount and platform to be used with ball link rods
-- Original carriage but for use with ball link rods
-- Top endstop bracket (so that idler bracket can be put above for belt tightening)
-- Bottom belt spreader
-- Bottom corner support (for better case stability)

I used Traxxas 5347 ball links. They have just enough movement to cover the whole printing area. They are sold in packs of 12 (what are the odds :), are readily available in model shops here in the UK and reasonably priced too (~Â£7.50) More photos from my Rostock build: https://plus.google.com/photos/102205917688348138845/albums/5794445797670248865 To use the SCAD files you need:
  • configuration.scad from https://github.com/jcrocholl/rostock
  • lm8uu-holder-slim_v1-1.scad from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16158

comments.text:
Hi, I'm not entirely sure what you mean... The idler (the part with the pulley) doesn't have the endstop switch mount - it's the other part that attaches to the top side of the printer. I put the idlers above the top side to facilitate tensioning of a fixed-length belt loop. Check the photos of my Rostock.

Well, it was quite straightforward - I glued the screw in using hot-melt glue and then screwed the plastic body of the ball joint onto it. If it was out of position when screwed all the way in I just pushed a bit harder to get it into position :)

Thanks! I bought 6mm OD/4mm ID carbon fibre tubes from an eBay kite shop. The length depends on the size of your Rostock printer; I think the original Rostock uses 250mm rods.
I used M4 screws to attach the ball ends to the tubes. I first cut the heads off the screws and then used hot melt glue to glue the screws into the tubes with about 5mm of thread sticking out. The screws were a bit loose in the tubes so quite a bit of glue was needed. 5 minute epoxy would work better.

comments.text: Looks like they built this model in sketch up, but I do this type of work in AutoCAD often without trouble. Â Because AutoCAD is a solid modeler, it's well suited for 3D printing. Â I combine as many solids as possible with the union command prior to exporting, and use the BREP command on particularly complex solids, or any solid that refuses to combine with the rest. Â My understanding is that BREP erases the solid's "history" of smaller shapes and simplifies it. Â Netfabb Basic is also good for running simple cleanup scripts on STLS before printing. Â

title: MMC - SD Card Holder for CTC 3D Printer

description.text:
A memory card holder that can be clipped onto the side of a CTC 3D Printer (A clone of either a MakerBot or FlashForge). I designed V1 using Sketchup after finding out that the other MMC holders don't quite work properly with my CTC clone. 05/11/2014 -
I just uploaded V2, a redesign using Autodesk 123D Design. Although the software has much to learn from Sketchup when it comes to drawing in 2D, In my opinion it does offer better 3D manipulation than Sketchup. Case in point: it was easier for me to round-out the edges of V2 using 123D Design than it was to bevel the edges of V1 when I used Sketchup.

Just print the STL file on your 3D printer. I recommend printing the "thing" on it's side otherwise you will want to include printing support structures for the overhanging clip (which is what I did). My settings when I print:
Infill 10%
Shells 2
Layer height .20mm
Support On - (Only when not printing "thing" on it's side) The slots for the memory cards are intentionally loose so that you can easily pick them out and insert onto your CTC. It is my hope that older Makerbots and Flashforge printers with the plywood enclosures are also 5mm thick which would allow the clip to work with them as well.

title: Parametric Make: Math Monday Linkage Bar

description.text:
Recently Make: has been running a series on linkages:
http://blog.makezine.com/2012/07/30/math-monday-linkages-an-introduction/ for which they provide the MoMath Linkage Kit as a PDF that you can print out or laser-cut. Or, if like me you have a 3D printer and no laser cutter, you can print them out :) As a bonus, the bar lengths are engraved in the bars with triffid_hunter's 8-bit number function. Note that so far, I have satisfactory bars but no connectors yet; suggestions welcome.

You'll need the MCAD and openscad-bitmap libraries.
Edit the top of the OpenSCAD file to set the linkage size. The way it's set, everything's scaled down so that the longest bar (60 units) fits diagonally on my ~190x180 mm print bed, with 4mm units.
Then, edit the next section in the OpenSCAD file to set specific bar lengths and print each one out.
Check out Make:'s linkage series, build linkages, and post photos here.

remixed_from.author: papergeek
remixed_from.title: MakerFarm Prusa i3 Magma cooling system remix

title: MakerFarm Prusa 8" i3v Magma Cooling System

description.text: I really loved the "MakerFarm Prusa i3 Magma cooling system remix" that PaperGeek made... (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:161066) ...but on the newer, Prusa 8" i3v (laser cut version with V-track extruded aluminum), there is an M5 nut at the back of the X idler trolley that gets in the way. Bummer. So I pulled the STL files in and reworked the wedge and the main duct, and I turned the fan adapter on it's side so it could be printed flat, and... Voila! I hope other i3v users find this helpful. I'm able to get up to ABS temperature (225C) in less than 3 minutes with this installed. It used to take up to 10 minutes. One note, though, if you follow Colin's instructions for assembling the Magma hot end, your ceramic heater will be more towards the FRONT of the extruder trolley. This brings it REALLY close to the fan adapter in this kit (it will melt/deform), so you'll want to re-build your Magma hot end so that the heater block (and thermistor) are towards the BACK of the extruder trolley. This is not SUPER difficult, just a bit tedious. You can insert the ceramic heater from either side of the block, so you'll have to remove it and insert it from the other side.

I got the original STL files, brought them into SketchUp, and reworked the problem areas:
  • Added a rounded indent into the WEDGE piece so that the M5 nut is cleared
  • Reworked the WEDGE part so that it has more thickness (and stability) above the flat part
  • Moved the two retaining tabs on the MAINDUCT closer to the extruder hole so the new WEDGE doesn't collide with them
  • Thickened the M5 bolt sleeves inside the MAINDUCT because the i3v seems to have problems with the thin walls there
  • Added two small tabs on the sides of the updraft exits of the MAINDUCT to more easily retain the FAN ADAPTER
  • Turned the FAN ADAPTER on it's side in the STL to make it easier to bring into Slic3r
  • Didn't alter the FAN SHROUD
    • When constructing, I did the following things:
  • Glued the FAN ADAPTER to the MAINDUCT with Acetone, allowing unit to be handled as one piece; the tabs on the bottom of the FAN ADAPTER go under the front lip of the MAINDUCT, and the two individual wedged screw holes are at the top, getting thicker as they go inward towards the MAINDUCT
  • I used two spare 30mm M3 bolts left over from the MakerFarm i3v build and sandwiched the Magma cooling fan between the FAN ADAPTER/MAINDUCT assembly and the FAN SHROUD
  • YES, trying to get the WEDGE inserted while the Magma head is in the way is FRUSTRATING! I recommend tapering the leading edge of the WEDGE so it's easier to insert without breaking the TABS, then, when you're trying to put it together under the extruder, it's easier
  • The two M5 nut holes help hold the MAINDUCT in place until you can get the whole thing screwed into the base of the extruder block
    • Hope this helps. Pics to follow, I promise!

comments.text: This is great!  I had printed out the papergeek version, but couldn't get the fan adapter to print- too tall and thin, i guess.  Was just about to lay the adapter down flat and make some relief for the M5 nut when I happened across this.  Saved me a little work, thanks!

title: Filament spool holder and rotating dispenser

description.text:
Here is a horizontally rotating, low friction dispenser for a spool of filament.
All you need are x5 16mm ball bearings.
You could adapt the gasket to cope with whatever ball bearings you happen to have lying around.
Simply lay your spool on its side onto the ball bearings and watch your filament feed through to your 3D printer effortlessly.
50mm core and 35mm core spools are provided for. But its very easy to adapt the core to fit whatever size you require.
I will produce more as I need them.
Also used in Thing:316951 as a Lazy Susan for entertaining.

Print out the base, gasket and whatever size core base you need.
Place the core base on your table,
Put the base on top of the core base,
Put the Gasket in the base,
Put your ball bearings in the holes in the gasket,
Rest your spool on the ball bearings with the centre of the core base coming up through the spool core.
I have found it seems to work best with the spool placed more than 30cm from 3D printer feed. The slack in the filament can then cope easier with any retraction movement.

author: thowe

title: Rolling Plinth
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Really surprised there wasn't one of these already on here, so I made my own.  
This is for the herbal connoisseur in your life and allows you to put together a nice fat one with a little more ease and less mess.
Also is very good for making Rolll ups.  If you want one exclusively for roll ups, simply scale the Z to 65%.

Printer:

Prusa i3 Mk2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.4

Infill:

0 - 50% see notes.

Notes: Always print vertically otherwise the sloping part prints badly and ruins the design. Do not use any brim at all, its a PITA to remove; see Post Printing notes. Three ways to print 1 Solid Layers 0.1 to 0.4 0.1 = 50% infill, 3 Perimeters
0.2 = 40% infill, 3 Perimeters
0.3 = 30% infill, 3 Perimeters
0.4 = 20% infill, 3 Perimeters 2 Hollow Layers 0.1 to 0.4 0.1 = 4 perimeters 0% Infill
0.2 = 4 Perimeters 0% infill
0.3 = 3 Perimeters 0% infill
0.4 = 2 Perimeters 0% Infill 3 Spiral Layers 0.3-0.4 - any lower and the object becomes to flexible to use adequately. Personally I prefer method 3, using 0.35 layer height for strength.
You may need some fine grade sandpaper to clean up the bottom layer edge as it can catch on your rizla when moving it half off the plinth to pick up the cigarette.

Sketchup
Based on a offcut piece of metal that a friend had which he used for the same purpose.  I simplified the design and created in sketchup.
I also used a small blue rubber hammer and an electric sprout for inspiration.

title: DSLR camera rig half-shoulder rest - thing-o-matic printable

description.text: This is a derivative of one of the parts (shoulder_holder_160.stl) that Flummer posted that makes it compatible for printing on a thing-o-matic. Basically the original part prints the whole shoulder rest in one print, and it's just too big to print on my thing-o-matic. So I chopped it in half, filled the original holes, and put new holes in place. Instead of one hole per half, there are two, so there should be no problem with stability when the shoulder rest is clamped to the rails. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/aVRoEzQC9Fa

Print two copies of this thing, and then print four of the "shoulder_holder_bracket.stl" things found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29677 ... this bracket part holds the shoulder rest to the rails.

Using the following options: total_height = 60
finger_size = 23

desired_word = FRESH
total_width = 95

After looking all over for the different options, I decided to purchase a smartrap kit after putting it together then I realized that even though it is a great design and fulfill it function, it have some flaws and precision its one of them, so O decided to redesign it in order to make it more robust, adaptable and more precise with the use of bearings and timing belts, Y axle is expandable and if you want to expand X you will only have to modify Mode 2 and print another Mode 5 for it's support (you can crop it or use the second stepper motor housing for a second extruder.
This is a work in progress, I'm getting the printed parts and stuff can change before it's completed.
Please, all advise and recommendations from you are welcomed. Update:
As printed parts gets done and tested, I found that some little modifications were needed. mostly cosmetic and few extra room for bearings. So almost final parts were updated. Next week i will have all parts ready for final assembly and testing, I will upload a video in YouTube .
The Amazing people from Makercoast has printed the parts for me, their printing quality and customer service is top notch, and Suraj is a great person and very professional.
Update 05/16/14:
Printer was put together, will test it tomorrow and will report about it. I will be modifying Mode 10 and Mode 5 a little since Mode 5 tries to incline and Mode 10 is not doing it function of holding it straight. the original design was for attaching Y axis to Mode 5 straight out, and that's what i end up doing after taking the pictures. Sorry for the wire mess, it will be fixed after i get everything calibrated and working properly.
Update 08/06/2014:
Sorry for not reply on time to your questions. I just added the modifications i did to get my printer working without any issues. the main problem that i found with my printer was that Mode 5 was not heavy enough to hold the X axis and will bent sideways and Mode 10 was not holding it, once i re-design this two parts and stiffened the X axis support ( 60% infill and 3 perimeters) my printer worked just as i wanted (even though i designed it to stand alone, it will have to be bolted to a board to hold steady).
there is some odd parts that i had on hand and used to design this printer, the heatsink is a 50 mm instead of 40 the fan is a 60mm one, and the block that holds the throat was drilled to accommodate 4mm bolts. of the fan shroud, i cut some of the upper tabs, since it was hard to reach the nozzle throat some times.
Conclusions: It is a good printer, it has its limitations specially in regards to printing speed because no matter how solid the X axis support is, if you try to print too fast it will tend to vibrate, i figure out a way to fix this "not pretty" but if the axis support and the end of the x axis piece is modified to link them with a nylon cable, the vibration issue will be eliminated and the printing speed could be increased. If anyone needs the original files, please let me know and i will try to concert the to your format, the are originally made in Inventor 2014.
Thanks

title: Case for Atmel's ATSAMA5D36 development board

description.text:
This uses the ATSAMA5D3-XPLD board, based on an ARM Cortex A5.
http://www.atmel.com/tools/ATSAMA5D3-XPLD.aspx It also uses the 4.3 inch display from PDA.
http://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/90-00002-A0/1230-1000-ND/

Cut out the supports with a razor blade.  
You'll need at display ribbon cable of at least 200mm in length.  This is because the 'XPLD board doesn't simply fold back on the PDA display.  
Before you touch the display ribbon connectors, let me warn you they are very fragile and are only rated for about a dozen insertions.  Go slow.  Be patient with them.  
There is a large cut-out in the case for the side buttons of the PDA display.  There is also a large cut-out in the case for the Ethernet connectors.  If both of these large cutouts are on the same side, structural integrity of the case is compromised.  A design with the 'XPLD board turned 180 degrees solved this problem, but requires a 200mm cable.  
The two hoods are for the connectors on the back of the PDA display. Once mounted, they come very close to the back of the 'XPLD board, so it was prudent to make covers.  
Mount the first rail on the side of the PDA display with the cable.  The cable runs through the slit in this rail.  Mount the cable on the PDA display board, carefully thread the cable through the slit in the rail, THEN secure the rail.  Secure both screws of the first rail.  
Install the screw which will go in the "slip hole" of the second rail, so it is not too tight to disallow the screw, but tight enough to be snug when the rail is in place.  You won't be able to tighten this screw later.  
Carefully fold the ribbon cable and place the board in position in the first rail.  Then carefully mount the second rail while simultaneously making sure the cable stays in between the boards and aligning the 'XPLD board with its slot on the second rail.  ;-)  You'll know why I inserted the smiley face after you do this. :-p  
What you have now simply drops into the case.  There is a protuberance on each inside corner of the case.  These will snap over the rails you just mounted, holding the unit in the case.   
There should be enough room for one Arduino shield, depending on the shield of course.   
You can remove the unit from the case by gently prying the side with the PDA display buttons.

description.text:
This is a sweet bazooka for the Davincibot. Which can be found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:31496

Hot glue a #4 finishing washer to the bazooka, such that the base is facing down. Try to center it as best as possible. I did not create a recess for this washer because I didn't want the accessory to get too thick. Hot glue a 5mm diameter spherical magnet to the hemispherical recess on the front of the bazooka. Make sure the poles are aligned by placing the magnet in a spare finishing washer while gluing in the magnet. Stick it on your Davincibot and pretend to blow stuff up! I have included the openscad file for you to fool with if you wish. Check out this instructable for more details:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Davincibots-Create-a-3d-printed-modular-robot-toy/

To best take advantage of your new MakerBot PLA Filament Sample Pack, you can print this 0.25 lb spool holder and attach it to either side of the back of your MakerBot Replicator Desktop 3D Printer (Original) or MakerBot Replicator 2 Desktop 3D Printer.   
We recommend printing with standard settings, with a raft and no supports. To attach the spool holder, tilt it and insert the rectangular end into one of the openings on the back of your MakerBot Replicator 2 or MakerBot Replicator (Original). Tilt the spool holder back down to lock it into place.  
We remixed davidatkinson's original design, "Dave's Spool Holder," to fit the MakerBot PLA Sample Pack.

We recommend printing with standard settings, with a raft and no supports. To attach the spool holder, tilt it and insert the rectangular end into one of the openings on the back of your MakerBot Replicator 2 or MakerBot Replicator (Original). Tilt the spool holder back down to lock it into place.

title: DSLR Shoulder Rig - Dual Parallel Std Clamp A, thing-o-matic printable

description.text: This is a derivative of one of the parts from Flummer's DSLR shoulder rig.  The "dual parallel standard clamp a" part is too wide to print on a thing-o-matic, so I chopped it in... roughly half... and added the finger joint to join the two parts together.  I was curious to see if the stacked halves would print ok, and they do.  the finish is a bit rough on the top half. Oh well.

You will need to a 1/4"-20 bolt or something equivalent to secure the two halves together, but I've found this to be really stable and rigid otherwise. The fingers are snug and the say the filament tends to be laid down lends a good amount of rigidity when they're stacked against each other and mechanically tightened down. Once the part has finished printing, you should be able crack the support fingers away from the bottom half that were holding up the finger joints of the top half. Then you can carefully take a razor and slice the two halves apart. Warning! Razors are sharp and you can hurt yourself if you're not careful! This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/jkVyhiDhgwC

title: Very simple Lego City Trains tracks

description.text:
These are iterations of the already available tracks on thingiverse. I have just simplified them as much as possible. Always use the files that are higher in version, they are more refined. Edit:
21-04-2016
  • added a new version of the combining junction, larger and should work without problems now
  • added modular tracks, print 1 of each end to connect to the lego tracks and then as many modules in the middle as you need.

V2 tracks need support enabled. The tracks where I drew inspiration had support integrated but I found that support not to my liking. Support generated by any slicer is much better and can be removed easier. V2 are also better adapted for PLA printing, the first version is better suited for ABS (shrinks a little bit). The junction in this first version is only combining two tracks from one direction and going only straight from the other direction.
If time permits, I will update it into a full workable junction. Added 2x12cm straight tracks for UP! mini printers.

title: Device for protecting a mobile phone
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Ultimately, all I need out of a phone case it to keep the camera lens from being scratched up. This happens because the phone sits directly on a table, floor, etc. and the plastic lens gets banged up.
So, this glues onto the back of the phone and raises the lens off the table. Problem solved. Expensive case not needed. This should be 1" in diameter when printed.

Print and glue this sucker right over the apple on your iPhone. I recommend using silicone glue so it can be removed.
If you want to sand this to smooth it up, put blue tape over the other parts of your phone, then sand it that way, otherwise, you'll scratch your phone.
Additionally, find the price of a case, then deduct that price from the cost of your printer. You can use this to justify upgrades to your significant other. (Also, if you can actually pull this off, it deserves its own post)

comments.text:
How about sanding it before you attach it to your phone?
I recommend using high strength epoxy to make sure it never comes off the logo. Saves unexpected embarrassment.
Non-commercial? Good thinking, this could really take off.
I don't own an iPhone, but I'm making this anyway. My significant other and I can use it to play floor tennis under the door. She really has a mean left paw!
comments.author: PropellerScience

comments.text:
You could do that, too. Or make it out of ABS and smooth it out with acetone.
Non-commercial is my default. If someone wants to sell something of mine, they'll have to ask. When you actually upload a design, I hope you'll license it in a similar way.
Also, I think this will work on any phone, really. You could stick it to your shoe even. That would be awesome.

title: 12v Power Supply Cover with standard cord and switch

description.text: This works with some 12v DC Regulated power supplies and a Intel Male Power Socket with Fuse Switch 10A 250V 3 Pin IEC320 C14

I have adjusted it. It should not be to tight now. I have not gotten a full print yet, but I have addressed all the issues that I have found. I have not printed this yet to verify all the measurements. I will mark it final after I print it. I have seen several of these. But I wanted to use the switch listed below. Power supply:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B007KG0ZYI/ref=oh_details_o01_s00_i00 Switch:
http://www.amazon.com/Inlet-Power-Socket-Switch-IEC320/dp/B00511QVVK/ref=sr_1_cc_1?s=aps&ie=UTF8&qid=1349228924&sr=1-1-catcorr&keywords=Inlet+Male+Power+Socket+with+Fuse+Switch+10A+250V+3+Pin+IEC320+C14 Modified files. Increased the size of the screw whole so that the M3 screw should fit through it. Wiring the switch. (120V) Use terminal crimp connectors. 5 female and 3 ring. I cut the ends off a PC power cord to get the wire. It is stranded and very flexible. You will need 4 pieces. My wires were green, blue, and brown. Green is ground. 5 inches with a female and ring crimp connectors. Blue/white is neutral. 5 inches with a female and a ring crimp connectors. Brown/Black is line. Two wires. 2 inches with female crimp connectors on both ends. 5 inch with a female and a ring crimp connector. Looking at the back with the switch at the bottom. The top center one is ground. Connect the Green wire female crimp connector. The ring connector goes to the ground terminal of the power supply. The next one down on the left is neutral. Connect the Blue/white wire female crimp connector. The ring connector goes to the neutral connector of the power supply The next one down on the left is the line. Use the 2 inch Brown/Black wire with 2 female crimp connectors. Connect it to one of the switch connectors on the right. Connect the 5 inch Brown/Black wire with a female and ring connector to the post directly to the left of the one you just connect the previous wire to. The ring connector goes to the Line terminal of the Power supply. Make sure you put a 10A fuse in the switch. Note: I bent the female crimp connectors so that they didnâ€™t stick out. Make sure there are no bare wires. You are working with AC!

comments.text: I finally completed my build of the cover. I actually decided to mount an XT60 connector as a panel socket on the front. The distance between your screw holes happened to be exactly right to hold the connector from moving backwards and forwards. I describe it here: http://bukobot.com/adding-a-12v-dc-power-cable-connectorhttp://bukobot.com/adding-a-12... and there's come pictures.
comments.author: buildrob

comments.text: Interesting. My switch was assembled in the other orientation - with the slightly narrower spaced terminals on the left rather than the right. So using left and right to disambiguate these is obviously not a good idea. For your wiring instructions of course it doesn't really matter as you not using the neon lamp. [I edited my last comment to remove reference to left and right.]
comments.author: buildrob

comments.text: Hi NewtonRob, the way I wired the switch was that each of the active and neutral terminals on the socket were wired to one of the left-hand switch terminals. The corresponding right-hand switch terminal is then connected to the power supply terminals (in my switch make the neon is connected across the two right-hand hand switch terminals - you can see this when you look at the switch terminal closely). The wiring instructions you gave wouldn't light the neon - but that may have been your intention. Yeah I used a 5A fuse for 240V which is consistent with your recommendation of using a 10A for 115V. Cheers.
comments.author: buildrob

comments.text: Oh, Yea.  You are using 240 volts.  The instructions I provided were for 120 volts.  So it will be different.
comments.author: buildrob

comments.text: If I'm in the US and have my S 350W 12V power supply set to 115, does this switch work?  Electronics newbie so forgive the dumb question.
comments.author: mpavia

comments.text: I am in the US and I am using this switch.  Make sure you get a 10A fuse (This is a small fuse. I have been able to find the fuses online.  You might be able to find 6 Amp fuses at the Lowes or Home Depot).  I know the power supply is 30 Amps.  I know that the printer is not using 30 Amps (11 to 15 amps).  There must be a conversion from AC to DC.  I have not blown a fuse and it is working very well.  The switch is what you would find on a power supply for a computer.  I really like being able to use a normal power cord to power my printer.  This way no one sticks fingers where they shouldn't.
comments.author: mpavia

comments.text: One last question (i hope) did you solder the wires on inside the switch or use something else?  I see you recommend ring connectors but how did you attached them to the leads on the switch?
comments.author: NewtonRob

comments.text: Solder will work.  Just hard to solder on the posts.

A small being offers you his enormous artistic utensil for your utilization! This is a great model for painters! This little guy can hold your wet brush without the bristles needing to touch anything or get junk stuck to them! It also works for pencils and pens if you just want an amusing holder at the office!

Just a little something I whipped up in Blender for fun. Keep him from face-planting: I scaled this guy x1.5. From legs to shoulder, mine is about 60mm and can hold a sharpie. I also used a rectangular fill pattern with a .4 density. You'll just need to glue the arms in place. (I like to use a mix of the same color filament and some acetone or nail polish remover as my adhesive to keep the same color, but use your preference.) The head doesn't need to be glued together but can be. It snugly fits in the neck hole so it is not necessary.

comments.text: Hey, sorry for getting back so late. It did not fit - but I thought it was due to the miserable printing quality. While printing, the whole thing lifted from the printer and warped. So I used a file to make it fit. Probably the toughest points are the edges, you might round them off. It's one of my earlier designs and I made it with no gap between the lid and bottom edges - and your x/y problem sounds like your axises are not equal (which is never ever the case - my design just doesn't give any room for deviances). I will upload the updated lid in a second and a separate bottom as well. Thank you for sharing your results!
comments.author: QuantumCheese

comments.text:
That's cool! Your probably right about the XY thing, i measured the internal dimensions of the green bottom i printed and it is 51.2mm x 51.4. which is pretty damn close, (the other two had similar XY differences) It is the first square thing i have printed so far, so at least i now know that and can compensate for it if req.
I wondered if yours was a bit warped while printing or a close-up lens effect! I had a couple peel up at the edges while i was still at the 'trying to get ABS to stick' stage, Since starting to use ABS juice, and a slightly larger raft, the corners rarely peel but it can prove a bit difficult to remove now!!
Printing the new lid now, will update when complete.

title: UP Mini parts for entire extruder replacement with an extruder from China (MK8)

description.text:
UP Mini parts for entire extruder replacement with an extruder from China (MK8). All wiring colors match. New mag base is required to position the longer stepper motor and get the nozzle back to center of the build platform. Use all the old electrical plugs from the UP Mini hot end, stepper motor, and fan.
You have to use the hot end thermocouple from the Mini since the one supplied will not work with the Mini software. The UP Mini thermocouple fits perfectly and works even though it sticks out a bit. There is a set screw under the insulation surrounding the hot end just for the UP Mini thermocouple. Do not over tighten.

The new extruder assembly is from eBay. http://www.ebay.com/itm/121281423242
Two holes are carefully drilled into the aluminum heat sink on the new extruder to mount the UP Mini printed circuit board holder. I used two #2 x 5/8" sheet metal screw.

comments.text: Got any images of parts you've printed with the new extruder?
comments.author: IcanCwhatUsay

comments.text: Not with this mag mount. After mounting the MK8 I replaced the control board with a Ramps/Arduino set up. I have only printed a couple of small things but it looks very similar to the original UP Mini set up. I am also using Simplify3D which is very similar to the UP software with respects to the support removal and quality.

comments.text:
Update:
I measured the Mini extruder gear against the new extruder gear and
came up with a radius difference of 1mm. The new extruder gear measures 5.5mm
radius and the old Mini gear is 4.5mm radius. I removed the new larger gear and
shoved the Mini gear on and it is a good press fit. I aligned the Mini gear
center with the filament roller guide center and it seems to work great so far.
The center line of the filament through the extruder is off slightly but it
doesn't seem to matter. On my first print I noticed the detail was better than
the prints were with the 11mm gear that came with the new extruder.
comments.author: jeeplvr

author: jeeplvr

description.text:
This is a three colour print of an old banana. I can tell it's old because of the black marks on it. I've been taught that this is how you can determine how ripe a banana is.
Put together in Sketchup. Printed on a Replicator 2.

To print this out, you need a Replicator and the newest firmware to print the gcode as is. 1) Print VUW fixed.gcode (base colour)
2) Preheat the heated platform after print completes
3) Load new colours in (Left: Black | Right: Yellow)
4) Print VU LBRY.gcode It might be a good idea to gently press down on the bottom left side of the platform for a moment while the second file starts. This will ensure no contact is made with the base and hot-end. I had no real issues while printing this out. STL files provided if you want to re-slice using different settings.

title: Wellington Harbour, including Petone and Wainuiomata

description.text:
A relief of Wellington Harbour. The vertical scale is not constant, the shore line has been exaggerated to emphasise where the water starts.
The scale of this model is so small that it doesn't print very well. All the valley details are lost. Enlarging part of the model would probably work well.

I have been playing with ways to make a printable model of New Zealand locations. I've included a brief description of the workflow for anyone else who may be interested (including myself in a few months when I've forgotten how I did it).
I got the height information from Koordinates.com (https://koordinates.com/layer/3741-14-palmerston-north-15m-dem-nzsosdem-v10/) This gave me a huge TIFF file.
I used Photoshop CS6 to crop the image. Then I used the Image -> Adjustments -> HDR Toning to adjust the gray levels and emphasise the coastline. I am going for an easily recognisable model rather than an accurate one. Then I used the Create New 3D Object -> Mesh From Depth Map -> Plane and exported the result as an obj.
Then I used Meshmixer: Select -> Edit -> Extrude -> z axis to create the printable.
Easy as that! I have created two YouTube tutorials of this process.
Photoshop: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yLE_TklD0oE
Meshmixer: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pwZOgcqB1RY

author: mrbenbritton

description.text:
This is an updated version of the unique spinning top I designed in Sketchup. This version is a allot stronger in the weak spots so it is easier to remove from the build table. I also increased the angle so it prints cleaner with the Replicators default settings. It is designed to be printed in two pieces and glued together also to have an open space in the middle to test the spanning ability of the MakerBot Replicator. both top and bottom are printed at the same time then assembled with 4 drops of superglue at the "corners". I can also post separate .stl files for those of you who want to print it in two colors. See it spin!
http://youtu.be/3aZnpRYkkaE

Instructions
  • Print Spinning top V3 simplified.stl (I deleted superfluous geometry)
  • do not use raft or support
  • Assemble with one small drop of super glue on the flat part of each "corner"
  • Align carefully and squeeze each of the four flat spots together
  • Wait for glue to cure and Spinn!
    • Notes
  • Do not use a raft, the parts on the build platform need to be flat and smooth so they can be glued together.
  • Be careful when removing from build surface. It is super strong when the structure is complete but It can be a bit weak before the top and bottom are joined together.
  • It will print really well with default replicator setting.

comments.text: I sliced with MatterControl and it treated the joined geometry as a subtraction so basically the arms didn't really connect to the center and it fell apart. I have seen this when I built models with overlapping geometry and didn't merge them with a Boole. But maybe other slicers don't have this issue. I might try it again using a different slicing engine. It does look like a cool top.

title: UltimakerMultiMotorMount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a frame to mount multiple extruder motors to older style ultimakers that only have place for one. The electronics can handle two hot ends, and so can the flying head, but there was only room for one extruder motor. This frame solves that problem by allowing four (why stop at two?).

Cut this out of 6mm or 1/4" plywood with a lasercutter, cnc router or whatever you prefer to cut plywood with. Measure out where you wish to mount it and drill one of the holes. Level the frame and mark/drill the other holes. Add the spacer things between the mounting frame and UM backside and screw it together with M3 bolts nuts and washers. You may wish to add some glue when you are happy as I've had some reports of the holes being insufficient after longer use.

title: Ink Peg PLA Injector - Quick Colour change

description.text: This second generation Inker will allow quick colour changes of your natural PLA, without the need for complicated mulitple extruders or changing over PLA reels.

1) Print out 2 of the STL file
2) Attach the sides to a peg
3) Cut a bit of kitchen sink sponge and put a bit in both sides.
4) Fill sponge with ink, I found the best ink is the printer ink.
5) Make a few of these with different colour mixes.
6) Clip the colour you want to the filament above the extruder then print away in colour.

title: 50mm Calibration Slab for checking inside dimensions and thin walls

description.text: I printed out a 1 inch calibration cube and got my Printrbot LC calibrated really accurately.  Or at least I though so until I printed something with inside features (holes and other openings) which turned out to be way too small.  I made this 'cal slab' so I could check a number of sizing parameters after tweaking my printer and Slic3r configurations.  It's only 6mm tall because I have had not issues with Z calibration.  I also added a number of thin walls to try and get an idea what my actual extrusion width is (which turns out to be much larger than Slic3r thinks)

Print the slab, grab your calipers and compare the actual dimensions to those on the drawing (the pdf file)  
Designed using Cubify Design.  I highly recommend this $200 package for serious designers.

title: Sony E-Mount (NEX) adaptor for Diana F+ Lens

description.text: With this adaptor, you'll be able to mount Diana lenses, like the Lomography Glass 75mm Diana lens reproduction, directly to your Sony NEX camera or E-Mount compatible body. The lens clicks in to place just like lomo's nikon and canon adaptors. There are two parts - the adaptor, and the aperture. This allows you to create new apertures, or even shoot without one for a wide open fuzzy look.

Print the main adaptor without supports. I used .2mm layer height and PLA, and that worked great. Print the aperture upside down at a higher quality if you can. You might need to use some pliers to twist it in to the adaptor body. Neither part required supports or a raft on my Makerbot Replicator 2.

description.text: These coins can be used as replacements for games that use pocket change for tokens. They're designed specifically for Adam P. McIver's Coin Age (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:316780), but they can also be use to play other games like Mapple (http://www.cheapass.com/freegames/mapple). Each coin has unique elements to distinguish it. The coins are sized similarly sized to pocket change, ranging in size from quarter to dime, and are slightly thicker than traiditional coins (3mm thick) to make them easier to handle as tokens. Of course scaling is always an option (though the surface details may suffer if made too thin). One side has traditional numerals on it, the other side has roman numerals, but pausing the print and changing filament at the 50% mark to a different color is a way to make the sides even more distinctive. If you like my work I hope you'll consider supporting me on Pateron: https://www.patreon.com/3DPrintingProfessor Subscribe to me on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/mrjoesays

Pausing the print and changing filament at the 50% mark to a different color is a way to make the sides even more distinctive. If you like this you should check out my other board game related 3D printables.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:316780
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:311400
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:166725

I printed the top 2 layers in blue, and the middle in black.  Came out quite nicely.   But I was only able to do the bottom ONE layer in red, and the black shows through too much, saturating the color.   If the roman 1 was deeper, then I could have done 2 layers of red and had really awesome high visibility pieces.

description.text: This 3D printed version of the PnP board for Adam P. McIver's Coin Age game (http://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/146130/coin-age). This board has distinct 3D features for each zone and recessions for coins or 3D printed coin tokens (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:316778). The card size version takes up only slightly more space than the credit card size of the original board, if slightly thicker, but would still fit in a dress pants pocket. Be sure to download and print out the rules for Coin Age to play with at http://bitly.com/CoinAgePNP If you like my work I hope you'll consider supporting me on Pateron: https://www.patreon.com/3DPrintingProfessor Subscribe to me on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/mrjoesays

For greatest effect change filament colors at regular intervals. Change the deluxe board every 6mm, change the card board every 2mm. Start with light green or yellow for the Plains of Kashe, then gray for the Silver City, then dark green for the Forests of Coindor, then tan or brown for the Copper Peaks and finally white for the peaks of the mountains. If you like this you should check out my other board game related 3D printables.

title: TAZ3 Salvaged Gateway All-in-one Fan Mount

description.text:
Didn't have a small fan so I designed a shroud for a fan I had on hand so in true hackerdom I salvaged a fan from a gateway all-in-one computer and started to design a mount.  This the the 5th generation and final design that works very well.  
My first OpenSCAD project and seemed a simple hack was all that was needed to move the current fan that mounted to the right  around to the front and open the fan mount opening to match my fan.   I added legs that extended on ether side and mounted fan in front of the extruder and bolted to the existing mount holes.   New to 3D printing I quickly learned about de-laminating.   The design was flawed.  The spindly legs would snap with any pressure.  
Back to the drawing board.  
2 more designs mounted the fan to the side and one in front of motor exhausting to the right.   while this mounted fine and was printable,  it turns out the added weight was enough to torque the extruder just enough to chatter when passing over the print.  
Design 4 located the fan above the extruder head.  This eliminated the torque issue.  The fan laid flat just above the extruder gear.  This required a wide duct down to the nozzle.  
The final design.  The fan is mounted above the extruder head and exhausting to the right through a slim duct to the nozzle.  All clearance is maintained with no loss for print volume.  
The nozzle was shamelessly stripped, hacked and modified from the original TAZ3 fan upgrade source files included with the machine.  The nozzle's basic shape and bolt mount locations is all that remains of the original.  
OpenSCAD file included so it can be modified for other similar fans.  I tried my best to keep it all parameterized,   but to be honest, there are quite a few tweaks here and there.  Is my first real project in OpenSCAD so YMMV.  
Prints on a fan less TAZ3 with PLA in 4 hours. I included my .35 layer sliced gcode.  
Will update with wiring instructions once I have worked that out,  just manually switching fan on atm.

1 - salvaged fan from a gateway all-in-one computer
2 - M3-20 machine screws.

comments.text: Its a tight fit.  The nozzle probably does not need to be as close as it it.  it works but on bridging the occasional strand lifting can get hit by the nozzle.  some light filing gave more clearance and eliminated the issue.   Will lift the nozzle a bit in future revisions.
comments.author: chiphead420

title: Futaba FC16 / F14 Transmitter Case Clips

description.text:
They get lost more than once.
Because they get loose with time and are of black color.
Now i have a couple of red ones, so the chance to pick them up from the grass again is increased. This part is critical in that the material must not shrink.
If it does, the clip will be too loose for pressing the case parts together. I got mine made from red PLA, which is working fine. The Clips do not fall off from alone; even if i wish they would have been minimal tighter. The solution would be to scale the part down by 2..5%, depending on the material and on the age / condition of your transmitter.

A drinks holder to be screwed to the side of a swinging garden seat.

Inspired by the "Barrel and Ball Puzzle" first described in
Professor Hoffmann's "Puzzles Old and New" published by F. Warne (1893). Pop a marble in the barrel, close it up and pass to a victim to remove.

Print AllParts.stl and add a marble.
This thing uses Karl Maximilian's screw thread library (Thingiverse 31363) place the screwthread script in the same directory.
If the screw thread is too tight/loose adjust the tolerance in the OpenScad script and just generate/print the BarrelEnd part. The thread should be tight enough to prevent the base of the barrel being turned just using finger pressure.
The marble should have a diameter of 15 or 16mm.
The barrel does use quite a bit of material in the upper half to enable the top to be printed - any suggestions on how I could minimise this greatfuly received as I'm new to OpenScad/3D design!

A spice rack meant to hold the slim supermarket spice jars.
You can print many of them, and clip them together.

Print out at least one box.
Print out appropriate clips to join them. Clips should connect both top and bottom, which is why there are gaps in the corners of the bottom of the box.

Hold the world in the palm of your hand!  
Based on the Unisphere built for the 1964 World Fair.   The Gridded Globe was created by Michael Curry  for Bre Pettis' UPS ad in the October 2012 issue of WIRED

The Gridded globe is designed to push the outer limits of 3D printing, and is an ambitious print for an experienced user.
The Globe is designed to be printed in PLA on a printer equipped with active cooling, such as the MakerBot Replicator 2.  Printing at lower speeds will yield better results.

Just a little gimmick and a printing test:
A sunken coffee mug...

The main part is "SunkenCoffeeMug_Top", but the snipped off bottom,
as well as the complete mug, for reference, are available too.
The bottom part comes in two different versions, a "even more
sunken mug" and the original, snipped bottom, rotated for
direct print. The image shows a 60% size printout.
I really tried hard printing this at 100%, without any
support, but I failed.
The handle itself does not provide enough stability.
Because nothing else helped, I added a custom, 100% fill
raft under the handle. But still, above 4-5cm, the handle tends to warp up and the
printing head kicks it from the platform. Anyway, at least my children like it ;-)

Preparation
  • put "Image2Raw.php" to your web server
  • create an "Input" subfolder
  • create an "Output" subfolder
  • Install OpenSCAD on your Mac
    • Batch-Converting
  • upload 150x150px images to "Input"
  • run "Image2Raw.php"
  • download the result "archive.zip" (location: "Output")
  • run "buildSTLs.sh" via shell for creating STL-files
    • ...done (after a while).

title: Lazy Susan rotating tray or turntable

description.text:
For those that entertain!
Here is a 115mm diameter Lazy Susan which should easily take a 250mm serving plate.
All you need are x5 16mm ball bearings or marbles.
Print this off, put it in the centre of your table and place a plate of fancies, Hors d'oeuvre or canapes; which guests can whizz around and choose at their leisure! Adapted from Thing:316500 which I created as a filament spool holder and dispenser

author: thowe

title: Wargaming terrain: "czech hedgehog" - anti-tank obstacle defence

description.text:
The Czech hedgehog (Czech: rozsocháč) or ježek, was a static anti-tank obstacle defence made of angled iron (that is, lengths with an L- or H- shaped cross section) deployed during World War II.  
Prepared for 28mm. Print 2x cross2.stl and use 1 cross3.stl to connecrt them.

comments.text: Is the cross 3 file supposed to print vertically or is the z axis flipped with the x?
comments.author: eliahu77

comments.text: No, the axes have flipped. It should be printed horizontally.
